Award.AwardTitle: Environmental Lipidomics of Suspended and Sinking Particles in the Upper Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plankton in the ocean play an important role in regulating Earth?s climate due to their role in cycling carbon dioxide. For example, some plankton use photosynthesis to convert carbon dioxide into the organic molecules that compose their cells. About a quarter of these organic molecules are lipids, which serve important roles as structural components of membranes, as energy reserves in oil bodies, and as signaling molecules. In some planktonic cells there are over one thousand different types of lipid molecules, each playing a distinct and essential role in the metabolism of the cell.

Planktonic lipids are also important for humans. They are measured by geoscientists in order to address a wide variety of problems, from understanding when life evolved on Earth, to estimating the temperature of the ocean in geological past, to assessing the health of plankton and their ability to conduct photosynthesis. Planktonic lipids are also the main components of petroleum, a critical energy source for transportation and industry. Finally, ocean plankton are the sole sources of many "essential" lipids that humans require in their diet but cannot efficiently synthesize themselves. Notable examples are eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), which in humans play key roles in cardiovascular health, hormone production, and inflammation management. On average, the global population of humans is chronically deficient in EPA and DHA. Seafood is essentially the only source of these essential fatty acids to the human diet, and yet we do not know if production of these lipids by marine organisms will be able to keep up with future global demand.

Despite the importance of planktonic lipids, geoscientists have only a basic understanding of lipid distributions in the ocean and cannot predict how lipids will change in response to future global warming. Results from lab experiments with cultures of phytoplankton suggest the potential for significant future alterations in the types and amounts of lipids produced in the oceans. The research being conducted as part of this project seeks to address this problem by producing the first global-scale assessment of lipids in the ocean. The overarching strategy will be to apply lipidomics, a state-of-the-art method for simultaneously analyzing all of the lipids in a plankton cell, to a library of thousands of samples from a broad range of ocean environments. These environments nearly span the global range in factors thought to affect plankton lipid metabolism. This project will shed new light on the identity, sources, and fates of the vast diversity of planktonic lipids, and enable scientists to predict and respond to changes in the future output of lipids from the ocean. The project will also inform our understanding of petroleum formation, and provide geoscientist with better tools for understanding Earth's history. The scientist would continue his efforts to train the next generation of scientists (postdoc), as well as his quest to educate the community and K-12 students via his science outreach endeavors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The upper sunlit part of the ocean is filled with tiny suspended cells called plankton. Among these, a group of cells called phytoplankton perform photosynthesis and create biomass from the sunlight. Phytoplankton are critical to the planet's health because they are food at the bottom of the ocean food chain and remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Due to this, the better we understand how plankton survive, the better we understand the ocean food web and global carbon cycle.

 

Plankton, like all other cells, are encased in a membrane of molecules called lipids. Lipids are useful molecules for understanding the internal biochemistry of cells. In addition to this, phytoplankton make many lipids that their animal predators cannot make but need in their diet. An example of these is the 'essential fatty acids' or 'omega-3 fatty acids'.   The fish in the ocean trace all of these essential fatty acids from the phytoplankton and the bottom of the food chain.  Humans, in turn, benefit from these same molecules when they consume fish.  Therefore, the nutrition of the whole ocean, and humans on land, relies in part on the amount of these unsaturated lipids that phytoplankton make.

 

In this project, we collected over 900 samples of lipids in the ocean from phytoplankton all around the globe. We also collected data on the temperature, light conditions, and other environmental conditions of the water where we collected the lipids. We used techniques to examine thousands of lipids molecules in each of these samples and then see how the environmental conditions are related to this composition. We found that the amount of some essential fatty acids are higher in colder places. This result is important because it shows that climate change might threaten the nutrition of ocean food webs with warming water. If water is too warm, phytoplankton may make fewer essential fatty acids, which in turn could deprive fish and other animals of these molecules they need. More research is needed to understand if warmer waters could disrupt food webs like this, but our project provides evidence that climate change could affect the nutritional quality of seafood. Given how much humans rely on the ocean for food and nutrition, careful understanding of this phenomenon will be essential to inform our actions. Our study lays the groundwork for this.

 

In addition to this key finding, an important outcome from this project is publishing all of the raw lipid data online for anyone to access. This will allow other researchers to use their own tools and search the dataset not just for the lipids we were looking for, but for other lipids they might be interested in too. Having a dataset where all the samples were collected in the same manner using the same techniques is useful because it makes data comparable. We hope these samples will be a resource for people understanding phytoplankton in the ocean.
